Hospitalization Record.Chief Complaint: Repeated respiratory infections, palpitations, and shortness of breath for 2 months

Present Illness.Onset: Symptoms started 2 months ago with no specific triggering event. Initially, patient noticed mild shortness of breath and occasional palpitations.
Present Illness.Main Symptoms: Patient reports progressive shortness of breath, frequent palpitations, and multiple episodes of respiratory infections over the past two months. Symptoms worsen with physical exertion.
Present Illness.Accompanying Symptoms: Cyanosis especially during infections; occasional lightheadedness and fatigue; no chest pain or syncope.
Present Illness.Diagnosis and Treatment History: Patient visited local clinic where she was treated symptomatically for respiratory infections but symptoms persisted. No previous specific treatment for heart condition.
Present Illness.General Condition Changes: Mental state appears slightly anxious; no significant changes in sleep or appetite; normal urination and defecation; slight weight loss of 2 kg reported.

Past History.General Health Condition: Generally healthy for age, managed hypertension.
Past History.Disease History: Hypertension for 10 years, managed with medication.
Past History.Immunization History: Up-to-date with basic immunizations; Flu and Pneumococcal vaccines administered last year.

Personal History.Living Habits: Non-smoker, minimal alcohol use, regular daily activities.
Personal History.Occupation and Working Conditions: Retired, previously worked as a school teacher.
Personal History.Exposure History: No known exposure to industrial toxins, dust, or radioactive substances.

Marital History.Children's Condition: Two children, both in good health.

Marital and Family History.Family History: Mother had diabetes, father had hypertension. No known family history of congenital heart disease.

Systematic Examination.Skin: Pale, cold and slightly cyanotic extremities.
Systematic Examination.Neck: No jugular vein distention, no thyromegaly.
Systematic Examination.Chest: Thorax normal shape. Lungs clear with no abnormal sounds. Heart - displaced apex beat, audible murmur.

Hospitalization Record.Specialist Examination: Cardiology assessment reveals a systolic murmur heard best at left sternal border.
Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination: Chest X-ray shows mild cardiomegaly. ECG reveals right bundle branch block. Echocardiogram indicates ventricular septal defect.
Hospitalization Record.Diagnostic Basis: Based on clinical presentation of repeated respiratory infections, palpitations, shortness of breath, cyanosis, confirmed by echocardiogram findings of VSD.
Hospitalization Record.Differential Diagnosis: Rheumatic heart disease (no history of rheumatic fever, no mitral valve involvement), anemia (normal hemoglobin levels), venous hum (innocent murmur not fitting the murmur pattern), common cold (symptoms persist and other signs support heart disease).

Post-Admission Course Records.First Course Record: The patient was admitted due to symptoms suggestive of congenital heart disease. Initial diagnostic investigations including echocardiogram confirmed a ventricular septal defect. Treatment plan includes symptomatic relief for respiratory infections and cardiology consultation for potential long-term management.
Post-Admission Course Records.Daily Course Records: Day 1: Patient stabilized, symptomatic treatment for respiratory infections. Cardiology consult arranged. Day 2: Patient showing mild improvement in respiration. Awaiting further test results.
Post-Admission Course Records.Senior Physician Rounds Records: Senior physician confirmed congenital heart disease, advised conservative management with close monitoring.
Post-Admission Course Records.Stage Summary: Patient condition improved, stabilized under conservative treatment. Plan for outpatient follow up with cardiology.
Post-Admission Course Records.Consultation Records: Cardiology consult: Recommended conservative management due to patient's age and overall health status. Routine follow-ups and monitoring suggested.

Medical Orders.Long-term Orders: 1. Administer oxygen therapy as needed for respiratory distress. 2. Continue antihypertensive medication. 3. Monitor vitals regularly. 4. Arrange follow-up with Cardiology.
Medical Orders.Temporary Orders: 1. IV antibiotics for current respiratory infection. 2. Analgesics for pain relief as needed.

Hospitalization Record.Auxiliary Examination Reports: 1. Chest X-ray: Mild cardiomegaly. 2. ECG: Right bundle branch block. 3. Echocardiogram: Ventricular septal defect.
